questions.text:
Match the following hormones to their respective receptor's target of action.
Hormone Target
1. Thyroid hormone A. Receptor tyrosine kinase 
2. Insulin B. Adenylyl cyclase
3. Atrial natriuretic peptide C. Intracellular receptor
4. Norepinephrine D. Guanylyl cyclase
questions.solution:
The correct option is Option 3: 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

1. Thyroid hormones C. Intracellular receptor
2. Insulin A. Receptor tyrosine kinase 
3. Atrial natriuretic peptide D. Guanylyl cyclase
4. Norepinephrine B. Adenylyl cyclase

Thyroid hormones act on intracellular receptors (intracytoplasmic or intranuclear) to induce the transcription of selected mRNAs, thereby promoting protein synthesis. Other hormones with similar action include steroid hormones and retinoic acid.

Insulin activates the tyrosine kinase enzyme on the intracellular (cytoplasmic) portions of transmembrane receptors, thereby phosphorylating the receptor. Other hormones with similar action include EGF, PDGF, M-CSF

Atrial natriuretic peptide increases intracellular cGMP by activating the enzyme guanylyl cyclase. A similar mechanism of action is seen with nitric oxide (NO).

Norepinephrine acts on intracellular adenylyl cyclase enzyme via beta-1 (adenylyl cyclase activation to increase cAMP) and alpha-2 (adenylyl cyclase inhibition to decrease cAMP). It activates phospholipase C and increases the production of DAG, IP3, via alpha-1 receptors.

questions.text: Urea cycle and Krebs cycle are linked at the enzyme____.
questions.solution:
Urea cycle and Krebs cycle are linked at the enzyme fumarate.

In the Urea cycle, cleavage of argininosuccinate to arginine releases the aspartate skeleton as fumarate.

Fumarate in Krebs cycle, by addition of water, converts to  L-malate.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents to the outpatient department with fever, epigastric discomfort, progressive weight loss, arthralgia, and foul-smelling diarrhea for the past 6 months. There is no relation between the abdominal pain and his bowel movements. He was started on a restrictive diet, which showed no improvement. His biopsy is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of this patient along with the given slide showing macrophages filled with PAS-positive inclusions point to a diagnosis of Whipple's disease.

The morphologic hallmark of Whipple disease is a dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria. Macrophages contain periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant granules that represent lysosomes stuffed with partially digested bacteria.

Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by a gram-positive bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It is characterized by a triad of diarrhea, weight loss, and arthralgia. Malabsorptive diarrhea of Whipple's disease is due to bacteria-laden macrophages that accumulate within the small intestinal lamina propria and mesenteric lymph nodes causing lymphatic obstruction. Extraintestinal symptoms may precede malabsorption.

Histopathological findings: 

  • A dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages is seen in the small intestinal lamina propria; these macrophages contain PAS-positive, diastase-resistant granules, which indicate partially digested bacteria with lysosomes—a hallmark of Whipple's disease.
  • With disease progression, there is villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and apoptosis of surface epithelial cells in the intestine, which can cause diarrhoea due to decreased absorption and increased efflux of water and solutes.
  • Non-caseating granulomas may also be seen.
  • Bacteria-laden macrophages can accumulate within mesenteric lymph nodes, synovial membranes, cardiac valves, brain, or other sites.

The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is primarily established by endoscopic biopsy and histological evaluation. The remainder of the cases are diagnosed by PCR which can be done on duodenal biopsies or fluids (such as CSF and synovial fluid) or tissues.

Other options:

Option A: Irritable bowel syndrome presents with recurrent abdominal pain that may be related to defecation, associated with a change in frequency, or associated with a change in appearance. Despite having these symptoms, the endoscopy and microscopic examination are normal in patients with irritable bowel syndrome.

Option C: Cystic fibrosis is a congenital disorder due to a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene located on chromosome 7. It leads to abnormal transport of chloride and bicarbonate ions in the lungs, gastrointestinal tract, pancreas, and reproductive tract. 

Option D: Celiac disease is an autoimmune gluten-induced enteropathy where there is an excessive inflammatory response to gluten and its breakdown product, gliadin. This leads to inflammatory infiltration of the lamina propria which subsequently impairs various nutrient absorption.

Image: Microscopic image of celiac disease

questions.text: The incision preferred during autopsy in case of asphyxial death due to neck compression is?
questions.solution:
The incision preferred in the case of asphyxial death due to neck compression is the modified Y-shaped incision.

In strangulation, hanging, and any condition where the larynx might be damaged, modified Y-shaped incision is to be preferred, as the skin of the upper neck can then be dissected off the mandible and raised clear to give a wide approach to the neck structures.

Y-Shaped Incision: Commences at anterior axillary fold on the chest on either side, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at xiphisternum in the midline and then run downwards as in I-shaped incision to the symphysis pubis. It is preferred in females. It is more cosmetically accepted as the incision and the stitches are minimally seen after the autopsy. 

Modified Y-shaped incision: An incision is made in the midline from the suprasternal notch to the symphysis pubis. The incision extends from suprasternal notch over the clavicle to its center on both sides and then passes upwards over the neck behind the ear. Indicated in cases of strangulation or death due to compression of the neck. 

I-Shaped Incision: Extends from symphysis mentii to symphysis pubis taking curve towards left around the umbilicus. It is used routinely in practice. It is simple and convenient.

Elongated X-shaped Incision: This is a special incision used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries, which are usually missed where superficial imprints are faint, particularly when present on skin not overlying bone. This is helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death and should be practiced in cases of custodial death.

Note: This MCQ has been revised for factual accuracy. For a detailed explanation about the incisions, refer to the link - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539901/ .

questions.text: Which of the following is part of trotter's triad, seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma?

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss, Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia,Palatal paralysis
Sensorineural hearing loss, Contralateral  temporoparietal neuralgia,Palatal paralysis
Sensorineural hearing loss, Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia,Palatal paralysis
Conductive hearing loss, Contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia,Palatal paralysis

questions.solution:
Trotter’s triad seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma consists of conductive hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, and palatal paralysis.

Trotter’s triad consists of the following:

  • Conductive hearing loss due to Eustachian tube obstruction.
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to involvement of the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) which presents as facial pain.
  • Palatal paralysis, due to involvement of the vagus nerve(CN X) which presents as palatal asymmetry.

questions.text: Retrolental fibroplasia is also known as _________.
questions.solution:
Retrolental fibroplasia is also known as retinopathy of prematurity.

  • Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP), previously known as retrolental fibroplasia, is a disease of the eye that affects prematurely born babies.
  • ROP can be mild and may resolve spontaneously, but may lead to blindness in serious cases. As such, all premature babies are at risk for ROP, and very low birth weight is an additional risk factor.
  • Both oxygen toxicity and relative hypoxia can contribute to the development of ROP.
  • Location
    Concentric zones centered on the optic disc are described.
    • Zone I is bounded by an imaginary circle, the radius of which is twice the distance from the disc to the center of the macula. 
    • Zone II extends concentrically from the edge of zone I; its radius extends from the center of the disc to the nasal ora serrata.
    • Zone III consists of a residual temporal crescent anterior to zone II
  • Stages of ROP:
    • Stage 1: Demarcation line
    • Stage 2: Intraretinal ridge formation
    • Stage 3: Neovascularization
    • Stage 4: Subtotal retinal detachment
    • Stage 5: Total retinal detachment
  • "Plus" disease signifies a tendency to progression and is characterized by the dilatation and tortuosity of blood vessels involving at least two quadrants of the posterior fundus. 
  • Aggressive posterior ("rush" disease, AP-ROP) is uncommon but if untreated usually progresses to stage 5, sometimes within a few days. It is characterized by its posterior location, prominence of plus disease, and ill-defined nature of the retinopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following water-related diseases is transmitted by a vector that breeds in the water?
questions.solution:
Filariasis (B.malayi) is transmitted by Mansonia species of mosquito that breeds in water.

Water related diseases are classified as:

Category

Examples
Water-borne diseases

Caused by the ingestion of water contaminated by human or animal faeces or urine containing pathogenic bacteria or viruses; includes cholera, typhoid, amoebic and bacillary dysentery and other diarrhoeal diseases.
Water-washed diseases

Caused by poor personal hygiene; includes scabies, trachoma and flea-, lice- and tickborne diseases in addition to the majority of waterborne diseases, which are also water-washed.
Water-based diseases

Caused by parasites found in intermediate organisms living in water; includes dracunculiasis, schistosomiasis and some other helminths.

 
Water-related diseases transmitted by insect vectors

Caused by vectors that breed in water; includes dengue, filariasis, malaria, onchocerciasis, trypanosomiasis and yellow fever.

questions.text: Mass drug administration is not done for __
questions.solution:
Mass drug administration is not done in case of vitamin A deficiency. 

Mass Drug Administration(MDA) is the administration of a drug to an entire concerned population irrespective of age and gender. For example, antimalarials are given as MDA in Malaria endemic island communities and in low-endemic non-island settings approaching elimination, where there is minimal risk of re-introduction of infection, good access to treatment, and implementation of vector control and surveillance.

Vit A prophylaxis is given under NIS only to children up to 5years. It is given as mass prophylaxis and not as a drug for treatment. Vit A as ‘treatment’ is only given to a child with features of Vit A deficiency and as such doses are not instituted to all in the community. Therefore, it is not considered under MDA.

On the other hand, MDA is done in worm infestation, scabies and filariasis.

questions.text: A young female patient is being evaluated for recurrent first-trimester pregnancy loss. On investigation, the activated partial thromboplastin time was prolonged, and the anti-beta 2 glycoprotein antibody was positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLA). 

APLA is characterized by recurrent thrombosis due to the formation of autoantibodies. It generally affects women. APLA should be considered in those under the age of 55 with recurrent thrombosis. The presence of at least one clinical and laboratory criterion is required for diagnosis. 

Clinical criteria: 

  • Vascular thrombosis with one or more episodes of thrombosis (arterial, venous, or small vessel) in any organ
  • Pregnancy morbidity
    1. With the unexplained death of a morphologically normal fetus after 10 weeks
    2. Premature birth of a morphologically normal fetus before 34th week due to preeclampsia, eclampsia, or placental insufficiency
    3. Three or more unexplained spontaneous abortions before the 10th week.

Laboratory criteria: 

  • Positive lupus anticoagulant (LA)
  • Positive anticardiolipin (aCL)
  • Positive anti-beta2GPI antibodies.

Treatment involves lifelong warfarin therapy titrated to a goal INR of 2.5-3.5. Aspirin may also be added at a dose of 80 mg. 

Other options: 

Option B - Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acute condition characterized by widespread intravascular fibrin formation in response to activation of the coagulation cascade. It is not associated with LA. In addition, this patient has a chronic history of recurrent DVT and pregnancy loss. Elevated levels of fibrin degradation products are sensitive for diagnosing DIC

Option C - Trousseau syndrome, also known as migratory thrombophlebitis, is a form of systemic hypercoagulability that arises from a paraneoplastic syndrome because of procoagulant factors. There would be multiple venous thromboses that appear, disappear, and reappear in another location. 

Option D - Factor VIII deficiency is seen in hemophilia. It is a bleeding disorder and is not characterized by recurrent thrombosis. It is associated with recurrent bleeding into soft tissues, joints (hemarthrosis), and muscles as a result of trauma or spontaneous mechanism. Lab values show prolonged aPTT.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presented with chronic projectile vomiting and weight loss. What is the expected metabolic abnormality to be seen here?

choices.text: Hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia
Hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypernatremia
Hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypercalcemia
Hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic acidosis with hyponatremia

questions.solution:
The expected metabolic abnormality to be seen in this patient is hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia.

The persistent vomiting results in these abnormalities along with paradoxical aciduria. 

  • Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-).
  • Kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3- causing hyponatremia. However, loss of sodium stimulates the secretion of aldosterone through the RAAS pathway.
  • The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions.
  • Loss of potassium ions leads to the development of hypokalemia.
  • Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It is called paradoxical aciduria since the body initially loses H+ ions due to the loss of HCl, and instead of compensating for that loss, the body is losing more H+ ions through urine.

questions.text: A 70-year-old chronic smoker is being evaluated for chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss. On examination, pallor was noted. Peripheral smear revealed macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils. Stool examination showed elevated calprotectin and a positive guaiac test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of Crohn's disease presenting as jejunoileitis. This is evidenced by the presence of features of malabsorption such as steatorrhea, chronic diarrhea, and vitamin B12 deficiency anemia.

The fecal calprotectin and lactoferrin are elevated in inflammatory conditions like inflammatory bowel disease, but not in irritable bowel syndrome. 

The stool guaiac test or guaiac fecal occult blood test (gFOBT) reveals the presence of microscopic levels of blood suggesting Crohn's disease. Gross bleeding per rectum is more characteristic of ulcerative colitis.  

Additionally, smoking is a risk factor for Crohn's disease. However, it is a protective factor in ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency with high-grade fever,  tachypnea, dyspnea, and cough from the last 2 days. His SpO2 was 88%. His chest X-ray findings are shown below. Which of the following is less likely to be considered as a differential?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the chest X-ray finding is suggestive of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and tuberculosis is less likely to be a causative disease.

Acute respiratory distress syndrome is a clinical syndrome characterized by acute onset, severe dyspnea, tachypnea, hypoxemia, and pulmonary infiltrates leading to respiratory failure. Etiological factors can be divided into direct and indirect causes of lung injury as follows:

  • Direct lung injury-
    • Pneumonia
    • Aspiration of gastric contents
    • Near drowning
    • Toxic inhalation injury
    • Pulmonary contusion.
    • COVID-19
  • Indirect lung injury-
    • Sepsis
    • Severe trauma like burns, flail chest, head trauma, multiple bone fractures
    • Transfusions
    • Drug overdose
    • Multiple transfusions
    • Pancreatitis
    • Drug overdose.

There are three stages in the development of ARDS:

  1. Exudative phase: Occurs for the first 7 days of the illness. The alveolar-capillary endothelial cells and type I pneumocytes are injured, with a breach in the tight alveolar barrier. Proinflammatory cytokines like IL-8, IL-1, TNF-α, and LT-B4 lead to the recruitment of neutrophils and the development of a hyaline membrane in the alveoli.
  2. Proliferative phase: Occurs from day 7-21. Recovery from mechanical ventilation is seen in most patients. Some patients may develop pulmonary fibrosis in this stage. Histological recovery is seen in this phase with a shift to lymphocyte predominant infiltrates. Type II pneumocytes proliferate and secrete surfactant with subsequent differentiation to Type I pneumocytes.
  3. Fibrotic phase: Is associated with increased mortality. Extensive alveolar duct and interstitial fibrosis are seen.

Chest X-ray features in ARDS:

Chest x-ray features usually develop 12-24 hours after initial lung insult as a result of proteinaceous interstitial edema. Within one week, hyaline membrane occurs due to type 1 pneumocyte damage. There are diffuse bilateral coalescent opacities consistent with pulmonary edema. 

Severity classification of ARDS:

  • Mild: 200 mmHg < Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 300 mmHg
  • Moderate: 100 mmHg < Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 200 mmHg
  • Severe: Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 100 mmHg

Management:

  • Mechanical ventilation with low tidal volume and high-PEEP.
  • Prone ventilation
  • Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation
  • Early neuromuscular blockade

Tuberculosis commonly causes respiratory failure in patients with extensive pulmonary parenchymal involvement, but it is a very rare cause of ARDS.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presented to the surgeon with a history of breast pain and a lump in her right breast for the past 2 months. On examination, the breast appears red, swollen, and has an orange peel-like appearance. This finding occurs due to:
questions.solution:
Orange peel like appearance, also called as Peau d’orange is caused by cutaneous lymphatic edema, due to the obstruction of subcutaneous lymphatics. It is the hallmark of inflammatory carcinoma.

Infiltration of Cooper’s ligaments (option A) leads to the dimpling of skin. Simple maneuvers such as stretching the arms high above the head or tensing the pectoralis muscles may accentuate asym­metries and dimpling.

Infiltration of the lactiferous ducts (option C) leads to nipple retraction.

Cancer-en-cuirasse: This is an aggressive form of cancer, where there is cutaneous and subcutaneous infiltration of the cancer cells. Its appearance has been compared to that of a metal coat (cuiras).

Note:

  • Peau d’orange indicates skin involvement in breast carcinoma.
  • Dimpling of the skin and nipple retraction do not indicate skin involvement.

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was discharged after removing the drain tube on the first postoperative day. On day two, the patient came back to the hospital with complaints of increasing abdominal pain and was febrile on examination. On ultrasound examination, there was a 5 x 5 cm collection in the subhepatic space. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests a bile duct injury following laparoscopic cholecystectomy leading to a bile leak. 

Bile duct injury

  • Usually is manifested in the postoperative period
  • Clinical features
    • Fever
    • Increasing abdominal pain
    • Jaundice
    • Bile leakage from an incision

Diagnosis

Imaging: Ultrasonography

  • To assess for a fluid collection and to evaluate the biliary tree 

Treatment strategy

  • Control of infection, limiting inflammation
    • Percutaneous drainage of periportal fluid collections
    • Parenteral antibiotics
  • Clear and thorough delineation of the entire biliary anatomy
    • Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) or percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC)
    • Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), especially if a cystic-duct stump leak is suspected
  • Reestablishment of biliary-enteric continuity (surgery)
    1. Tension-free, mucosa-to-mucosa anastomosis
    2. Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

 Option A: Infection is very unlikely to present in the immediate postoperative period with a pus collection of 5x5cms particularly after laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Option B: Surgical site pain will not be severe and diffuse instead it is localized and bearable.

Option D: Retained gallstones are very unlikely.

questions.text: Salivary gland tumor with a propensity for perineural invasion:
questions.solution:
Adenoid cystic carcinoma has a propensity for perineural invasion and indolent growth pattern.

  • It is the second most common malignant tumor of the parotid gland.
  • The histological types are tubular, cribriform, and solid.
  • The tubular type has the best prognosis and solid has the worst.
  • Treatment is the removal of the gross tumor with radiation therapy for microscopic disease.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A patient was brought following a road traffic accident. His pulse rate was 120 bpm, BP 80/40 mmHg, and the extremities were cold. Which of the given peripheral cannulas will you use during the resuscitation of this patient?
questions.solution:
For trauma patients who necessitate a high volume of fluid replacement and multiple blood transfers large-sized, wide-bored cannulas are preferred. Among the given options, an 18G size (green) cannula would be appropriate (larger cannulae have a smaller gauge number).

In the above image, the cannulae numbered 1 to 4 are respectively:

  1. 18G - green
  2. 20G - pink
  3. 22G - blue
  4. 24G - yellow

Hypovolemic shock is frequently caused by hemorrhage which can be external due to trauma or internal. The most common cause of internal hemorrhage leading to hypovolemic shock is gastrointestinal bleeding. Massive burns and vomiting are other causes of hypovolemic shock. 

The goal of care in this scenario is to improve volume status which can be done through the placement of large-bore intravenous lines (16 gauge or 18 gauge) and administering fluids.

questions.text: An incidental ovarian mass is found when evaluating a 19-year-old girl for kidney stones. The mass is removed and its contents are shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient with an asymptomatic ovarian mass consisting hair, bone, and sebaceous material is a mature teratoma. 

Teratomas are germ cell tumors. They contain embryonic tissues leading to the differentiation of cells along these pathways. There are three classes of teratomas:

  • Mature (benign) teratomas (eg: Dermoid cyst)
  • Immature (essentially malignant) teratomas (eg: solid teratoma)
  • Monodermal (highly specialized) tumors (eg: Struma ovarii)

Mature cystic teratoma, also known as dermoid cysts are unilocular in structure and have a smooth surface. They usually are lined by squamous epithelium with hair follicles leading to the formation of sebaceous material and hair. Other structures like teeth, bone, cartilage, thyroid tissue, and mucous membranes can also be found. 

Most patients are asymptomatic. Some patients may have symptoms because of the mass size of the teratoma. In other patients, ovarian teratomas can result in torsion of the ovary. Other rare complications include rupture of the cyst and spillage of contents into the abdominal cavity. 

Treatment of mature teratomas involves excision in order to prevent complications. Otherwise, mature teratomas are generally innocent. 

Other options: 

Option A - Immature teratomas such as solid teratomas of the ovary are solid and trabeculated. They also contain cartilage, bone, hair, and sebaceous material. There is no structural order. They are generally malignant. Grossly, they have a smooth external surface and are solid on sectioning. There may be areas of necrosis or hemorrhage. 

The following image shows both mature (left) and immature teratomas (right). 

Option C - Struma ovarii is a type of highly specialized teratoma that contains only thyroid tissue. If it is functioning, it may lead to hyperthyroidism. 

Option D - Granulosa cell tumors arise from the sex cords of the gonads. They are solid and generally produce estrogen. They can cause precocious puberty in children, hyperestrogenism in adults, and post-menopausal bleeding. They vary in appearance and range from microscopic to large, solid and cystic, encapsulated masses. If hormonally active, they may be yellow due to intracellular lipids.

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida who conceived after in-vitro fertilization therapy came for an antenatal checkup at 38 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history revealed that she was pregnant with DCDA twins. On examination, the first twin was found to be in a breech position and the maternal blood pressure was found to be greater than 140/90 mm Hg on two occasions with grade 1+ proteinuria. What should be done next?

choices.text: Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises
Terminate pregnancy at 40 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
Immediate caesarean section is done as the first twin is in breech presentation. Uncomplicated dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancies are terminated at 38 weeks of gestation.

Timing of delivery depends on the type of twin pregnancy:

Type of twin pregnancy Timing of delivery
Dichorionic diamniotic 38 weeks
Monochorionic diamniotic 34 - 37 weeks + 6 days
Monochorionic monoamniotic 32 - 34 weeks by Caesarean section

 Mode of delivery depends on the 1st twin:

1st twin presentation Mode of delivery
Vertex Vaginal
Breech Caesarean section
Transverse Caesarean section

After delivery of 1st twin, if the 2nd twin is in breech, assisted breech delivery is done. If the 2nd twin is in transverse lie, internal podalic version is done under GA in the OT followed by breech extraction.

Complications in attempting vaginal delivery in non-vertex presentation (i.e) transverse and breech:

  • Interlocking of twins
  • Fetal head trapping above the cervix
  • Umbilical cord prolapse

According to ACOG criteria (2019), preeclampsia requires proteinuria of grade 2+ or more. In a case of pre-eclampsia, termination of pregnancy must be done at 37 weeks.

According to the updated criteria, this patient does not have pre-eclampsia. Hence, Caesarean section can be done at 38 weeks as for any uncomplicated DCDA twin pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones (indicated by the arrow in the image below) giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A mother of five, brings her youngest child, an 18-month-old girl, for evaluation. The child appears very thin with minimal fat distribution. There is severe wasting of the shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs as shown in the below image. The middle-upper arm circumference is less than 11.5cm. The child is alert and irritable. What is the true statement regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The alert and irritable child with severe fat wasting in the areas of the shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs is likely to have marasmus due to calorie malnutrition.

Marasmus is a type of severe protein-energy malnutrition which occurs due to insufficient calorie intake. It is characterized by severe wasting of fat and muscles. The child appears to be very thin,  having a 'skin and bones' appearance with no fat. 

The loss of buccal fat leads to the 'monkey facies' or 'old man face' due to its aged and wrinkled appearance. 'Baggy pants appearance' is due to the presence of loose skin in the buttocks that hangs low. 

Other features that may be present are hypotension, hypothermia, and bradycardia as well as micronutrient deficiencies. 

Diagnosis of severe acute malnutrition is made with the help of anthropometry.

  • Weight for height is below -3 standard deviations for the mean on the World Health Organization (WHO) chart  or,
  • Presence of bipedal edema or,
  • Middle-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is less than 115mm (in the red zone of the tape as shown below). 

The children should be assessed for the following: 

  • Severe edema 
  • Low appetite (failed appetite test) 
  • Medical complications 
  • One or more danger sign

If any of the above are present, the child should be treated as a case of complicated severe acute malnutrition and should have inpatient management. Uncomplicated cases can have supervised home management. 

 

Kwashiorkor is another type of protein-energy malnutrition that is characterized mainly by pitting edema starting in the legs and feet that spread to the hands and face. They also show skin changes characterized by increased pigmentation and desquamation. They do not show signs of hunger and are difficult to feed. The weight for height may be normal. The following image shows the edema and the skin changes seen in Kwashiorkor.

questions.text: The knee deformity shown below is called as _____
questions.solution:
The deformity shown is genu valgum.

A normal knee has 5-7 degrees physiological outward deviation. Any increase or decrease in angle can result in knee deformities. 

Knee deformities are:

  • Genu valgus (valgum) or knock knee - Knees are abnormally approximated and the ankles are divergent.
  • Genu varus (varum) or bow knee - Knees are abnormally divergent  and the ankles are approximated.
  • Windswept deformity - Abnormal valgus deformity of one knee with varus of the other.
  • Genu recurvatum - Hyperextension at knee joint, knee bends backwards.

questions.text: A 1 -month-old girl, was admitted for the evaluation of fever. But there were inconsistencies in the mother's reporting of medical information. On further exploration, it was discovered that the mother had brought her children to multiple emergency rooms, giving inaccurate histories that prompted excessive testing. At one visit, she told clinicians that her 2-year-old son had lupus and hypergammaglobulinemia, and at another visit, that he had asthma and seizures. She also pursued a minor cosmetic surgical procedure for her son against his pediatrician's recommendation. Which of the following best describes this condition?
questions.solution:
Here, the inconsistencies in the history given by the mother, and the repeated tests and procedures done on the children because of mother's insistence points towards factitious disorder by proxy.

  • The most common case of factitious disorder by proxy involves a mother who deceives medical personnel into believing that her child is ill.
  • In factitious disorder by proxy, a person intentionally produces physical signs or symptoms in another person who is under the person's care.
  • One apparent purpose of the behavior is for the caretaker to indirectly assume the sick role.

questions.text: During resuscitation, a patient received a 20% Intralipid injection. What could have been the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Patients who are unresponsive due to local anesthesia toxicity require 20% Intralipid injection during resuscitation. 

Accidental intravascular injection of local anesthetic like bupivacaine results in bupivacaine-induced cardiotoxicity.

Initial management includes immediate initiation of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and defibrillation as per the advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) algorithm.

  • Following CPR, Intralipid therapy is initiated. A rapid bolus of Intralipid 20% IV (1.5 mL/kg) is administered without delay, followed by an infusion of 0.25 mL/kg/min. The infusion should be given continuously for at least 10 minutes after hemodynamic stability is achieved.
  • Intralipid decreases cardiac bupivacaine concentration by 11% within 3 minutes of administration, and cerebral bupivacaine concentration by 18% within 15 minutes.

Bupivacaine is a long-acting local anesthetic that is the most cardiotoxic among the local anesthetics. It depresses the rapid phase of depolarization in Purkinje fibers and ventricular muscle due to a decreased availability of fast sodium channels in cardiac membranes. This reduced rate of depolarization depresses myocardial contractility. Hence, bupivacaine is a potent cardio-depressant.

Note: Local anesthesia systemic toxicity (LAST) can also affect the central nervous system (CNS), which is more susceptible to local anesthetic action as compared to the cardiovascular system. Dizziness, tinnitus, and disorientation are the initial symptoms. Shivering, muscular twitching, and tremors follow. Tonic-clonic seizures occur. Finally, respiratory depression can lead to respiratory arrest.

questions.text: What is the following test called?
questions.solution:
The above image demonstrates Diascopy.

It involves pressing a glass slide onto the skin to compress blood in small vessels.

It is used in the following conditions: 

  • Lupus vulgaris: In detecting granulomatous nodules, which have a translucent brownish color known as ‘apple jelly’ nodules. 
  • Spider naevus: Application of pressure can compress radiating arterioles and allow visualization of pulsatile flow in the feeding vessel.
  • To differentiate erythema (vasodilation) from purpura (extravasated blood): Erythema disappears on compression of vessels, purpura, however, remains unaltered on compression.

questions.text: The skull X-ray of a patient who presented with bone pains is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows cotton wool skull which is diagnostic of Paget’s disease.

Radiological features during the early phase of this disease include osteolytic (lucent) regions which is later followed by coarse trabeculae and bony enlargement. Sclerotic changes occur much later in the disease process. The lesions seen are:

  • Osteoporosis circumscripta: large, well-defined lytic lesion
  • Cotton wool appearance: mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull
  • Diploic widening: both inner and outer calvarial tables are involved, with the former usually more extensively affected
  • Tam o'Shanter sign: frontal bone enlargement, with the appearance of the skull falling over the facial bones, like a Tam o' Shanter hat.

questions.text: Which of the following investigation is shown in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
The contrast radiograph given above is that of barium follow-through.

It is useful in visualising small bowel pathology. It is performed following a barium meal examination of the oesophagus, stomach, and duodenum. It is inferior to enteroclysis where contrast is administered through NG tube. It is also used to evaluate the function of the small bowel.

Barium meal examines the lower half of the esophagus, stomach, and entire duodenum.

Preparations and uses of Barium sulfate as a contrast in GI imaging:

  • Ba swallow uses barium paste (for esophagus).
  • Ba meal - 95% BaSO4 (for stomach and duodenum).
  • Ba meal follow through - 50% BaSO4 (for small bowel).
  • Ba enema -25% BaSO4 (for large bowel).
  • For Single contrast films, barium alone is used. Double-contrast films require air and barium which is better for a small mucosal lesion.

Contraindications to use of Barium:

  • Tracheoesophageal fistula: Dianosil-water soluble non-ionic agent is used.
  • Perforation peritonitis and esophageal perforation: Iohexol is used.

The above radiograph shows barium meal. 

Barium enema: contrast is administered through a rectal tube and series of radiographs are obtained. It still remains the investigation of choice to visualize fine mucosal detail and also a very good technique for demonstration of general colonic configuration and caliber. The above radiograph is double-contrast barium enema with normal large bowel structure.

Related Pearl: Barium Studies

Barium swallow: Used to assess the pharynx, esophagus, and stomach.
